metadata.title: Scalable performant solar cell module for CO2 Reduction Coupled with Organic Synthesis
metadata.author: N/A

Scalable performant solar cell module for CO2 Reduction Coupled with Organic Synthesis
Scalable performant solar cell module for CO2 Reduction Coupled with Organic Synthesis
A Data Management Plan created using DMPonline.be

Project abstract:
Project abstract:
Sustainable synthesis of fuels and chemicals from CO2 can be achieved by mimicking the light-harvesting and catalytic processes occurring in plants.
A viable artificial photosynthesis (AP) process is a grand challenge of scientific research, since it would not only alleviate the effects of global
warming but would also create an alternative solar, chemical, and energy industry. Prior works predominantly focused on developing lightsensitive
materials that can harvest solar light to excite the non-reactive CO2 molecules. Although this effort was on point, it was not sufficient for a lucrative
AP process. Recently, a more holistic approach for AP systems has been introduced, not only considering thebmaterials but also studying the whole
device and process design. This project aims to realize a breakthrough step in AP by designing and manufacturing a new type of lightharvesting panel
based on honeycomb-like repetitive structures using low-cost materials. These panels will improve the light-harvesting efficiency of the existing light-
sensitive
materials by increasing the active surface area and the efficient distribution of reagents. Moreover, to make the best of sunlight energy and achieve
maximum output, we suggest
replacing the sluggish water oxidation reaction with value-added organic molecules transformation which will open a new horizon to provide additional
economic value from the products The project aims to demonstrate the proof of concept with a complete scalable processing unit.
Last modified: 
Last modified: 
05-03-2024

A viable artificial photosynthesis (AP) process is a grand challenge of scientific research, since it would not only alleviate the effects of global warming but would also create an alternative solar, chemical, and energy industry. Prior works predominantly focused on developing lightsensitive materials that can harvest solar light to excite the non-reactive CO2 molecules. Recently, a more holistic approach for AP systems has been introduced, not only considering thebmaterials but also studying the whole device and process design.
